messages.message: First time tried the chat mode (on aihub.dev (http://aihub.dev)) with a sample bank statement and seeing incorrect result. See the attached the bank statement and query. Response excluded some transactions within the query date range and included extra outside of the date range. Not sure this is the right channel for this type of issues.
Model cant do math / date comparisons accurately. This is expected
ah.. so instead of responding with answer like this, can we block such queries?
Definitely something that can be thought of, not sure its in our immediate plans
Do we plan to have a disclaimer for user to validate the response? Issues like this will erode trust quickly.

@Vikas Mehta yeah, we are planning to put general disclaimers for sure.  this is a general pitfall of using GPT, and we have observed similar issues in other places as well.

We were having similar conversations with @Jarett yesterday as well.
There is a thumbs up / down feedback at the momet
That doesn’t really help @vineeth in this case no?

> Do we plan to have a disclaimer for user to validate the response?
Was just replying for this
Yeah it doesnt, but might help understand where its failing

I’m curious though — how are we planning to support any type of reconsiliation use cases if the model can’t do the math?

cc @Hari
@vineeth are there some guidance on what queries to write to get better results on this?
We are gonna enable agents, which basically would use calculators (python REPLs) to do math
Currently I would say its not supported, but we will definitely support it in upcoming iterations
We should document known issues in the product documentation. That way customers can’t say the product isn’t working as expected and initiate a defect claim/SLA demand

@shaunak @Vikas Mehta  GPT-4 is  better at math at this point. And as Vineeth mentioned we are planning to add some agents that will boost the math accuracy. We are definitely collecting these instances for now. Since Chat is free form op with no restrictions definitely disclaimer is going help define some boundary on what we can’t do/control right now.
looks like this startup (https://mathgpt.streamlit.app/) used streamlit (https://streamlit.io/) to easily integrate python into a natural language question + answer
